facts.text: Prithi Dubey died on July 14, 1932, leaving his widow Laung Kuer surviving, who succeeded as heir to his estate.

anchor.surface_text: One Prithi Dubey died on July 14, 1932, leaving him surviving, his widow Laung Kuer, who succeeded as heir to his estate.

facts.text: Laung Kuer executed a Zerpeshgi deed on June 21, 1935, in favour of Rajdewan Dubey and Kailash Dubey for Rs. 1,100 to discharge debts due by the deceased.

anchor.surface_text: For the purpose of discharging debts due by the deceased Laung Kuer executed on June 21, 1935, a Zerpeshgi deed in favour of two persons, Rajdewan Dubey and Kailash Dabey, who were also the next reversioners, for a sum of Rs. 1,100.

facts.text: Rajdewan Dubey and Kailash Dubey were the next reversioners.

anchor.surface_text: a Zerpeshgi deed in favour of two persons, Rajdewan Dubey and Kailash Dabey, who were also the next reversioners, for a sum of Rs. 1,100.

facts.text: The Zerpeshgi deed dated June 21, 1935 is binding on the reversioners.

anchor.surface_text: It is number in dispute that this deed is binding on the reversioners.

facts.text: On June 17, 1943, Laung Kuer sold a portion of the properties subject to the Zerpeshgi deed to the appellant for Rs. 1,600.

anchor.surface_text: On June 17, 1943, Laung Kuer sold to the appellant a portion of the properties which were the subject-matter of the Zerpeshgi deed dated June 21, 1935, for a companysideration of Rs. 1,600

facts.text: Out of Rs. 1,600 sale consideration, Rs. 1,100 was reserved with the purchaser for redemption of the Zerpeshgi, and Rs. 500 paid in cash.

anchor.surface_text: Out of this amount, a sum of Rs. 1,100 was reserved with the purchaser for redemption of the Zerpeshgi, and the balance of Rs. 500 was paid in cash.

facts.text: Rs. 100 from sale proceeds for repairs to family dwelling house, Rs. 200 for two bulls for agriculture, Rs. 200 for repairing a well constructed by deceased for public use.

anchor.surface_text: It is recited in the deed of sale that a sum of Rs. 100 was required to effect repairs to the family dwelling house, a sum of Rs. 200 for purchasing two bulls for agricultural purposes, and a sum of Rs. 200 for repairing a well, which had been companystructed by the deceased for user by the public and which was then in a ruined companydition.

facts.text: Appellant sought to redeem the Zerpeshgi but Zerpeshgidars refused to receive amount and surrender possession.

anchor.surface_text: After obtaining the sale deed, the appellant sought to redeem the Zerpeshgi, but the Zerpeshgidars refused to receive the amount and surrender possession of the properties.

facts.text: Appellant deposited mortgage amount in court under s. 83 of Transfer of Property Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant deposited the mortgage amount in companyrt under s. 83 of the Transfer of Property Act

facts.text: Appellant instituted Title Suit No. 69 of 1944 for redemption.

anchor.surface_text: and then instituted Title Suit No. 69 of 1944 for redemption.

facts.text: Reversioners (respondents) filed Title Suit No. 126 of 1943 for declaration that sale deed to appellant not binding on reversioners.

anchor.surface_text: Meantime the reversioners, the respondents herein, had filed Title Suit No. 126 of 1943 for a declaration that the sale deed in favour the appellant was number binding on the reversioners.

facts.text: Both suits tried together by District Munsif of Palamau.

anchor.surface_text: And both the suits were tried together.

facts.text: District Munsif held necessity established for all four items of consideration, sale binding on reversioners; dismissed TS 126/1943, decreed TS 69/1944.

anchor.surface_text: The parties were at issue on several questions of fact of which the only one material at this stage is whether the sale in favour of the appellant was supported by necessity and binding on the reversioners. The District Munsif of Palamau who tried the suits held on a review of the evidence that necessity was established in respect of all the four items of companysideration and that the sale was binding on the reversioners.

facts.text: Respondents appealed both decrees to Subordinate Judge of Palamau, who affirmed findings and dismissed appeals.

anchor.surface_text: He accordingly dismissed Title Suit No. 126 of 1943 filed by the respondents and granted a decree for redemption in Title Suit No. 69 of 1944 filed by the appellant. The respondents herein, the reversioners, preferred appeals against both the decrees passed by the District Munsif of Palamau and they were heard by the Subordinate Judge of Palamau, who, agreeing with the findings given by the District Munsif, affirmed the decrees and dismissed the appeals.

facts.text: Respondents filed Second Appeals Nos. 2155 and 2156 of 1948 in Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Against these decrees, the respondents preferred Second Appeals Nos. 2155 and 2156 of 1948 in the High Court of Patna.

facts.text: Laung Kuer died on March 14, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: While these appeals were pending, Laung Kuer died on March 14, 1952,

facts.text: On application of respondents, plaint in TS 126/1943 amended adding reliefs for possession and mesne profits.

anchor.surface_text: and on the application of the respondents, the plaint in Title Suit No. 126 of 1943 was amended by adding reliefs for possession and mesne profits.

facts.text: Patna High Court Bench of Rai and Misra JJ held sale deed not binding on reversioners, allowed second appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals were then heard by a Bench companysisting of Rai and Misra, JJ., who in separate but companycurring judgments, held that the sale deed in favour of the appellant was number binding on the reversioners.

facts.text: Misra J did not disagree with lower courts' finding of necessity for all four items.

anchor.surface_text: Misra, J., who delivered the leading judgment did number disagree with the finding of the companyrts below that all the four items of companysideration were supported by necessity.

facts.text: High Court granted certificates under Art. 133(1)(c) on November 27, 1956.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 645 and 646 of 1957 in Supreme Court from Patna High Court judgment dated August 1956.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 645 and 646 of 1957. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated August 1956, of the Patna High Court, in Second Appeals Nos. 2155 and 2156 of 1948.

arguments.claim: widow has full ownership, reversioners have only spes successionis

anchor.surface_text: When a widow succeeds as heir to her husband, the ownership in the properties, both legal and beneficial, vests in her. She fully represents the estate, the interest of the reversioners therein being only spes successionis.

arguments.claim: widow not trustee holding for reversioners; restriction on alienation incident of Hindu law estate

anchor.surface_text: Such a proposition could be supported only if the widow is in the position of a trustee, holding the estate for the benefit of the reversioners, with a duty cast on her to preserve the properties and pass them on intact to them. That, however, is not the law.

arguments.claim: widow has discretion on form of alienation (sale/mortgage) when necessity exists; powers like manager of infant/joint family

anchor.surface_text: Where, however, there is necessity for a transfer, the restriction imposed by Hindu law on her power to alienate ceases to operate, and the widow as owner has got the fullest discretion to decide what form the alienation should assume. Her powers in this regard are, as held in a series of decisions beginning with Hanooman Persaud v. Mussamat Babooee2, those of the manager of an infants estate or the manager of a joint Hindu family.

arguments.claim: no absolute prohibition on widow selling property subject to usufructuary mortgage if necessity; test is prudent owner

anchor.surface_text: Judged by these principles, when there is a mortgage subsisting on the property, the question whether the widow could sell it in discharge of it is a question which must be determined on the facts of each case, there being no absolute prohibition against her effecting a sale in a proper case. What has to be determined is whether the act is one which can be justified as that of a prudent owner managing his or her own properties.

arguments.claim: Dasrath Singh wrong insofar as absolute bar on sale of usufructuary mortgaged property

anchor.surface_text: In this view, the decision in Dasrath Singhs case1, in so far as it held that a sale by a widow of a property which is subject to a usufructuary mortgage is not binding on the reversioners must be held to be wrong.

arguments.claim: Lala Ram Asre Singh correctly states the law on widow selling mortgaged property

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment these observations correctly state the position in law.

arguments.claim: sale justified as prudent: redeemed portion, estate benefits from income

anchor.surface_text: It has been found in this case that Laung Kuer had to raise a sum of Rs. 500 for necessary purposes. She could have done that by mortgaging other properties, but that would have reduced the income available for enjoyment by her. On the other hand, by a sale of a portion of the properties covered by the Zerpeshgi deed dated June 21, 1935, she was able to redeem the other properties and the estate had the benefit of the income from those properties.

arguments.claim: concurrent findings of lower courts on necessity and binding nature not open to attack in second appeal

anchor.surface_text: The District Munsif and the Subordinate Judge on appeal have both of them held on a review of all the facts that the sale in favour of the appellant is a proper one binding on the reversioners. We are of opinion that this finding is not open to attack in Second Appeal.

arguments.claim: when conflict between High Court benches, follow previous or refer to Full Bench, not prefer later without reference

anchor.surface_text: When a Bench of the High Court gives a decision on a question of law, it should in general be followed by other Benches unless they have reasons to differ from it, in which case the proper course to adopt would be to refer the question for the decision of a Full Bench.

holdings.text: A widow is not absolutely prohibited from selling properties subject to a usufructuary mortgage if supported by necessity; validity depends on whether it is the act of a prudent owner.

anchor.surface_text: Dealing next with the points mentioned in the Order of the High Court dated November 27, 1956, the first question that arises for decision is whether a sale by a widow of properties which are the subject matter of a usufructuary mortgage is beyond her powers

holdings.reasoning_summary: Widow has full ownership not trusteeship; powers analogous to family manager; applies precedents like Hanooman Persaud; prudent owner test for form of alienation.

holdings.text: Dasrath Singh v. Damri Singh is erroneous insofar as it holds an absolute bar on widow selling usufructuary mortgaged property.

anchor.surface_text: In this view, the decision in Dasrath Singhs case1, in so far as it held that a sale by a widow of a property which is subject to a usufructuary mortgage is not binding on the reversioners must be held to be wrong.

holdings.text: Lala Ram Asre Singh v. Ambica Lal correctly states the law that a widow may sell mortgaged properties for necessity despite no personal covenant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Aligns with widow's full powers and liberty to choose sale over mortgage to preserve income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Privy Council, Full Bench precedents, and principles of judicial comity to avoid uncertainty; per incuriam exception noted but proper course is reference.
